reviewText:
I was quite excited when I first saw I, Zombie for sale. A game for casual gamers, where you can control your very own army of Zombies and cause havoc? I am game!

So, you have your very own little zombie and you are given your first tutorial mission. This mission is just to be sure that you know how to use the directional keys and understand the basic concept that if you are a zombie and try to close to an unarmed human, they will run from you. And if for some reason you manage to stand just long enough next to them, well.... yey, you just made a new zombie friend.

After the tutorial and the first couple of levels, you realise what I,Zombie will be all about -  a combination of a stealth / puzzler game, with a brief touch of RTS. All in all, it is a relatively short game, with only 20 levels. However, level design is solid. It has a nice learning curve and level difficulty increases gradually.

The soundtrack, in its never ending loop combines well with I,Zombie , and the visuals are quite nice for this little game. I particularly like the main zombie design, as it sort of reminds me a Tim Burton meets Simpsons combination. Oh well, Danny Elfman had already set that link before, so perhaps that concept isn't so far fetched.


In short, these are the things I can point out as positive in I,Zombie - The concept, level design, the soundtrack and the main little zombie. Seems like we are heading for a masterpiece!

Now the painful bit....

The first thing I have noticed after initial seconds of gameplay was that there controls weren't very responsive. There seems to be a lag between hitting a button and the character acting on it, and it becomes incredibly frustrating playing throughout levels of stealth without really knowing where your character's movement will end. I came to realise that as you lower the resolution, I,Zombie will run faster and the commands will become more responsive... but at this point I have started questioning myself if I it was fair to expect having fluidity issues with a Unity based game. However, lowering the resolution will reduce the game window, and if you fall lower than 800 x 600, I would recommend that you play it through with the aid of a magnifying glass.

Apart from unresponsive controls, I have often struggled with basic movement. More often than not, my little Zombie would get stuck on the edge of a box or some other obstacle, without being very clear why.

The combination of broken controls with some movement issues turned almost every level into a trial an error experience. And whereas in the first couple of levels I was still going for the 3 stars rating, the frustration soon took over me and my main goal became powering through the 20 levels I,Zombie had to offer.

Eventually I had another go in reaching max stars and beating I,Zombie in less than 15 minutes, in order to complete the achievements. Unfortunately this ended up as another disappointment, as for some reason they still appear as incomplete"

Apart from the nice basic visuals

If you're looking for a short game to master: I, Zombie can be quite rewarding.

reviewText:
I, Zombie is a collection of interesting ideas spread too thin over a handful of levels.

Going around levels, hiding from guards and sneaking up on helpless citizens to then turn into fellow zombies, to then turn against larger groups as you form an army is satisfyingly fresh yet immediately understandable. Rather than an all out assault much of I, Zombie is about positioning and sneak attacks as enemies have a limited field of vision but can still kill you quickly if they spot you far away. I loved getting the drop on patrolling guards and seeing my numbers grow, maneuvering my horde with a limited but effective number of commands as I infected every moving thing in the level. I, Zombie's biggest problem, again, is that it takes this mechanic and tries to do too much too quickly.

With only 20 very short levels (usually under two minutes if you do things right) there's very little time for the game to capitalize on its mechanics, peppering in different ideas throughout without giving them enough attention. It keeps the hour long experience varied, but I never felt as if the level designs were making much use of the enjoying ideas the game presents, merely showing some basic examples of how they work so you know how to use them before the difficulty catapults upward. Many of the later levels require infuriating amounts of precision to complete, often requiring you to follow an absolute line to get through them, and any deviation resulting in your very quick death. The final level in particular is such a poorly designed embodiment of trial and error that I ended up having to resort to watching a level walkthrough, and even then still had a great amount of trouble actually pulling it off.

I, Zombie is entertaining for what it is, but more often than not its attempts to make more interesting use of its mechanics is simply by raising the challenge in cheap and frustrating ways. I'd love to see the core of the experience spun out into a larger and more ambitious game, but for now it acts more as a proof of concept than something I can recommend.

This is pretty decent little action puzzle game, albeit with not much in the way of replayability beyond redoing the levels until you find the way to keep all your zombie minions alive on each level.

The gameplay is pretty simple - you start off a lone zombie who has to infect everyone in the level (with a couple of exceptions where you have to dodge the patrolling guards and just munch on the scientist at the end, and one case where you start off with a single turned zombie on the opposite side of the map with yourself trapped and unable to move), and each level basically you have to work out which groups of civilians or soldiers you should attack in what order, and with what timing on their patrol route in order to avoid getting your brains blasted out before you get to them. Early levels are pretty straightforward, the later levels tend to require a bit more planning of where to go and when, plus along the way there are a few tips and tricks you can pick up of how to manage your fellow zombies.

Your resources for each level are yourself - faster than the rest, and you control yourself directly with the cursor keys (or probably gamepad, haven't tried and the keys worked fine for me), and the zombies you have turned in the level so far which can be set to follow you, stay where they are, or attack the nearest non-zombie. Once you learn how to manage your brethren they can be used as a shield to cover your approach to a patrolling soldier, a distraction to let you get in closer before being shot at, or set up to attack the other of a pair of patrolling soldiers that are too far apart to just rush from one side. Your comrades can be a bit annoying and snag on the scenery occasionally, and they are really annoying to try and get past the sentry guns intact when a level requires that, but apart from those things the game plays pretty smoothly.

Once you have completed a level and survived you can move onto the next level, or replay it and try to find a way to complete the level without any zombies dying in the process, thus earning three stars. There are twenty levels (plus a training mission) to work through, and particularly the last half of them tend to be interesting and may take a while to figure out a good plan of attack, or get the timing right. Once that is done there is also potentially a bit of replayability trying to find a faster route to win each level, but beyond that it is not really the sort of game you will go back to again, as once you know how to do each level there isn't much more to gain from it. But it is quite fun to go through that one first time.

I, Zombie.  Casual Fun.  Be the Zombie.  Control the horde. Make more zombies.  Fun times.

- Trading Cards!  Achievements! Leaderboards! Yay!
- The dev for this game is fantastic.  Very accessible, responsive, positive, professional and will work to resolve any issue you might have.   (Yes, I had an issue that was quickly resolved by the dev).

In conclusion, it is what it is.  A great way to toss a little time.  Give it a go.

reviewText:
I'll be short and brutally rough, like this game: This is a money grab.  This looks to be an almost decent excuse for the game, made for either tablets or consoles, that was directly ported to PC, with no time whatsoever to change anything.  Literally, there is zero mouse function for this game.  I have not in my entire life since I played games on a Tandy not been able to use the mouse in gaming.  You will navigate the main menu & game with only the keyboard.  But as for the game itself...

The cheeky little intro video has IMO, the best thing about this game, the music.  I am not sure if it was done by the person whom made the game itself, but whoever did, if I was ever interested in working on a game with them, this would be the only area I would like to recruit them for.  The music is absolutely great, it is catchy, although repetitive, you don't get tired of playing it, though the short levels you'll be going through.  Oh, yes btw, every single level in the game is extremely short.

Because, after about 3-4 of the stupidly simple first few, you'll start to run into the problems of gameplay here.  Your zombie will quite easily get stuck on walls.  As in, NES times levels, stuck on walls.  This game is merciless in allowing you to make mistakes.  Generally getting stuck on a wall, or making a single mistake at the wrong time will cost you your one and only life, and then you restart the entire level.  Now, some of these levels do have some interesting ways you must finish them, so there is a slight bit of entertainment in the figuring out of how to sneak past the guards, and get to the unarmed civilians, which if you can manage to do, you can walk your zombie over to them, their health bars drop, and they become generic zombies under your control.  Now you may very roughly control them with essentially 3 commands: Stay in one place, follow me, go towards the nearest enemy head on and attack it.  These controls are barely good enough to bypass the levels if you are extremely patient, skilled & have a good sense of timing.

Speaking of patience, however, this game has even run mine out.  I have the patience of a Hindu ♥♥♥♥ing goat high on mushrooms and weed + Jesus Christ, but this ♥♥♥♥ing game...let's talk about the final level I am on.  I have looked up a video of how to beat it.  I have seen the man in the video able to do it, but he even had to stop his video, play the game for God knows how long, and come back to it once he had figured it out.  In the game the only enemies, are regular green soldiers, and special forces soldiers.  Now, green soldiers will shoot a single bullet at you, that if it hits, will both damage you, and slow you down.  (Who knew zombies had nervous systems, and were affected by things like getting shot.)  These soldiers after a few missions, aren't too difficult to deal with, as if you get to them, like normal civilians, if you damage them enough you can kill & convert them.  The special forces on the other hand, are a totally different thing.  They not only are armed with machine guns, which will spell almost guaranteed death if they hit you with even one bullet, but they are COMPLETELY ♥♥♥♥ING IMMUNE TO DAMAGE.  That's right!  You could walk up to them, and stand there all day long, with some sort of invincibility cheat/God mode turned on, and they will never die.  They are immortal enemies.  Frankly, this is a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t game mechanic.  It would have been like, having to fight Starman in Super Maro Bros.

In closing, I do not recommend this game, would not recommend this game, ever.  If anything, a soundtrack to this game should be sold, and the game itself taken off the market.  I bought it for 54 cents, and would not pay one for it now, or even DL it if it were free having played it.

I'd give this game 4/10, giving 3 points for the great music, and 1 point for the little bit of fun had while playing it.

reviewText:
After a full playthrough I can give an honest review.

This game has a wonderful charm about it akin to Zombieville USA on Android and iPhone. The colourful rounded artstyle gives way to an oddly cheerful zombie apocalypse. Art asside the gameplay is simple and easy to grasp, sadly though, there isn't much. Commanding your zombies and shambling about as a zombie yourself in this game leaves you feeling as if there could be more. Granted this game focusses more on timing and choosing targets strategically in order to finish the levels with minimal casualties for that 3 star score.

On the downside, this game feels like one of many Mobile to PC ports which brings with it a few bugs. One I found particularly troublesome was having to start as administrator because the game would totally lock up on the main menu shortly after launching. Another bug that was a little annoying was when controls were unresponsive for a short period of time, this usually fixed itself within the span of 2-3 seconds but was annoying none-the-less.

All in all for it's $2 asking price I'd certainly recomend it for casual gamers and achievement hunters alike.

I, Zombie actually kind of surprised me. I only got it because it was on sale. I wasn't entirely sure what to expect... it's labeled as strategy, but sometimes felt like a puzzle game, such as choosing the order and timing or how to avoid the ones you can't do anything about.

If anybody gets a perfect game all the way through on their first and only try in under 15 minutes, they simply cheated. It will take multiple (sometime several) attempts on many levels to get 3 stars and a low time, and you might not get both in the same run. The 15 minutes is a combination of best times for all levels, and since it could take several tries per level, that means it'll almost definitely take over 30 minutes and probably average over an hour. That's still not very long, but it's longer than 15 minutes.

It's worth the $2 if you like strategy or puzzle games, otherwise, there's still no reason not to try it out if it's on sale. If nothing else, you'll get some cards and achievements out of it.

So I picked this game up for $0.99 and boy, was it worth it. So the game is actually pretty fun- you play as the zombie and your mission is to eat every human and turn them into walkers, like yourself. The levels are designed to make you think and plan strategically- something that I didn't think the game would offer. I, Zombie NORMALLY doesn't have you blazing in, chomping off everyone's face, no, I, Zombie forces you to plan out moves and command your squad of walkers (if you have any) to get the job done. So yes, if you do end up infecting any other humans, they will turn into zombies and you can command them to do things such as stop, attack, or follow you.

Graphics
So even though this game isn't THAT old, it still looks pretty bad, if i do say so myself. Even at the highest resolution I can go (1440 x 900) the game will still look pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the game will be out of proportion with my monitor (meaning that there are those nasty black lines on the outer edges of the screen). If you're going to buy this for graphics, PLEASE, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, SAVE YOUR MONEY.

Gameplay
Lots of gameplay aspects were mentioned in the review up top, so I'll recap.
- Commanding your walker squad
- Planning out your moves
- Infecting guards/pedestrians to then infect others
Overall, gameplay mechanics are very smooth and effective. Nothing really seems overpowered.

Soundtrack
Very generic, nothing like death metal. It makes the game feel light, nimble, and fast. It made the game seem less violent then it actually should seem like. The soundtrack makes me feel like the game is rated E10.

Conclusion
Buy it- it's lots of fun and not really violent. Get it while it's on sale because it's seemingly on sale a lot and even then, the game only costs $1.99 on a regular day. 9/10

I,Zombie is a really fun game that anyone can pick up and put down really fast. I used to play between breaks at school, do 1 level here, 1 level there. I have to say that this is an extremely rewarding game to play. It causes you to think about all of your actions and strategize about the best and fastest ways to beat the levels. A few goods and a few not so goods to round out this review:

Good:
- Rewarding Gameplay: Easily the most notable feature. The levels are set up in such a way that it rewards you for your patience and strategy. (or for speed runs: SPEED)
- Leaderboards: Though just about everyone has gotten perfect stars on every level in this game, it then challenges you to see how fast of a speed run you can do to beat the levels.
- Challenging enough: The levels are challenging enough that you may get stuck on some for a bit, but they are never impossible, as long as you try to formulate some sort of strategy.

Not So Good:
Short: It's such a short game. I think I have 3 hours logged onto the game and I've completed it with all the achievements. That's not to say that this should deter you at all. It's a short game, but a really great game.
Semi-linear completion: Some of the levels are constructed in such a way that you have to comply to the level's mechanics to beat the level, meaning that on some levels, you may be able to have a few different choices of where to go to add to your zombie family first, while some, you will have to follow a set standard of how you beat the level. It's not terrible, but I think it would feel even better to have some more choices. Having said that, it doesn't take away from the gameplay.

That's really it! It's innovative and fun with really negligible shortcomings. I would definitely recommend this game. I got it on sale, but after playing it, I totally would have bought it at full price too.

If you can grab the game for few cents and you don't care about getting all achievements done go for it. Otherwise skip this one. It's a quality worth a dozens other free online flash games. Trying to get to 3 stars is purely lucked based in last levels, you can do everything correctly, but still anything of the following can happen: you get stuck behing an invisible obstactle that shouldn't really be there / soldiers decide to shoot your zombie first even though literally every other zombie's closer to them, which end the level for you / soldiers decide to finish the zombie they started shooting even though other zombies are closer, killing you zombies and not granting you that 3rd star. The fact that soldier's shooting and your bitting are animated with same time frame is annoying as hell as no matter that you stepped on the soldier in between his shots, you're still bitting the same speed and moment when he's shooting, which leads to so much moments of you dying the same moment soldier got changed it's beyond depresive.
A solid little game. Get it for cheap and it should provide some entertainment
A great game to play if you're bored.\nOr even if you're not bored.
